facts.text: On 14th March 1960, Government of West Bengal referred six items of dispute between four employers including appellant M/s. Serajuddin & Co. and their employees to Fourth Industrial Tribunal, West Bengal.
Items of dispute concerned claims for grade and scale, Dearness Allowance, House rent, leave and holidays, Provident Fund and Gratuity, and condition of service.
Workmen of three other concerns filed affidavits stating disputes settled, leaving only dispute between appellant and its workmen.
Appellant raised preliminary objection that under s.2(a) appropriate Government is Central Government, not State Government of West Bengal; reference invalid.
Tribunal overruled objection and set case for hearing on merits vide order No. 28 dated January 17, 1961.
Appellant's office at Calcutta (16, Bentinck Street) manages work of mines and sale of mine products; mining operations in State of Orissa under lease for chromite and manganese.
Calcutta office exercises general control over mining operations and looks after sale of minerals; staff at head office can be transferred to Orissa office.
Appellant employs staff at mine site for direct supervisory control.

legal_issues.text: Whether the industrial dispute between appellant and its head office employees at Calcutta is an industrial dispute concerning a mine under s.2(a)(i) of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, making Central Government the appropriate Government, or whether State Government of West Bengal could validly refer it.

petitioner_arguments.text: Head Office at Calcutta is integral part of the mine; industrial dispute concerning a mine under s.2(a)(i); appropriate Government is Central Government.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.2(a)(i), s.2(j), s.2(k) of Industrial Disputes Act; definition of industry wide enough to include head office

petitioner_arguments.text: Mining lease under Mines and Minerals (Regulation and Development) Act, 1948 includes disposing of minerals; sales from head office integrally connected with mining.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. d of Mines and Minerals (Regulation and Development) Act, 1948

respondent_arguments.text: Dispute not concerning a mine; head office not a mine; reference by State Government valid.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.2(a)(i) of Industrial Disputes Act; definitions in Mines Act, 1952

court_reasoning.text: Words 'industrial dispute concerning a mine' in s.2(a)(i) to be construed using dictionary meaning or Mines Act definition of 'mine', not broad definition of 'industry' in s.2(j).
court_reasoning.key_observation: 'Mine' excludes office; head office employees not engaged in mining operations or incidental work.

court_reasoning.text: Mines Act s.2(j) defines mine as excavation for minerals; s.2(k) separately defines office of mine; s.2(h) persons employed in mine limited to those in mining operations or connected work.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Head office work (sales) begins after mining operations over; not incidental or connected.

court_reasoning.text: Mining lease rights to dispose minerals do not expand 'mine' under s.2(a)(i).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No bearing on construction of s.2(a)(i).

court_reasoning.text: Central Government interest limited to disputes re mines as per Mines Act; head office outside; general rule State Government under s.2(a)(ii).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme of Mines Act excludes mine offices.

holdings.text: Industrial dispute at head office not concerning a mine; State Government of West Bengal appropriate Government; reference valid.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines appropriate Government; 'industry', 'industrial dispute', 'workman'; dispute not concerning mine

statutes_cited.name: Mines Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines 'mine' excluding office; persons employed in mine; used to interpret 'mine' in ID Act

statutes_cited.name: Mines and Minerals (Regulation and Development) Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines mining lease including disposal; held not to expand 'mine' under ID Act s.2(a)(i)

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave dismissed; Tribunal's order upheld; State Government's reference valid as dispute not concerning a mine.

key_quotes.text: the words 'in relation to a mine' must be construed without reference to the broad definition of industry prescribed by section 2(j).
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to rejecting petitioner's broad interpretation

key_quotes.text: The Head Office is not a mine and so, an industrial dispute raised by the employees engaged in the Head Office is not an industrial dispute concerning a mine.
key_quotes.speaker: court
